pages.title: Display Setup
pages.definition: A challenge as educators is to think beyond decorating the classroom and consider how the walls and areas of the room can be used effectively to promote curiosity, inquiry and creativity.
pages.benefits:
Classroom displays of children's on-going and finished work help to stimulate thinking and create dialogue, which in turn lead to new learning.

Displaying documentation of children's thought processes and conversations invites children to edit, revise and give further thought to their work. It gives teachers the opportunity to reflect on their practice. It also provides a way to bring parents into the life of the classroom.
pages.examples: A collaborative project to build a model of a roller coaster is set up in the center of the classroom, where all children can add to it as they develop new knowledge. A painting of a roller coaster is mounted with a simple black border so the details of the child's work stand out.

video.title: Classroom Displays

planningPoints.text: Teachers should look beyond decoration and plan meaningful and functional displays that change along with the classroom.

Coming up with ways to include hands-on displays should be a part of the formal planning of classroom activities.  To correspond with a unit about friction, teachers arranged for classroom families to donate simple materials like sand and scraps of fabric, which were glued to cardboard and displayed on a table to promote student engagement with the concepts.
Teachers planned for their students' 2D and 3D representations of textures to also function as a stimulating wall display.

Plan to take pictures of your students engaged in class projects. These photos can help children and teachers to reflect on their work, and they also help parents be informed members of the classroom community.

setupPoints.text: Classroom displays should be dynamic spaces for student work, as well as for thought-provoking objects that inspire children's thinking.
A table displaying hands-on books and materials becomes an interactive display designed to attract attention and encourage students' engagement.

Look for ways to allow individual and collaborative student projects to be the focus of your classroom display.  Here, students used clay to represent words that describe characteristics of matter.  The individual pieces are arranged to create a visual "chart" that supports students' thinking.
Keeping display boards simple and uncluttered allows children's work to be the focus. A bulletin board covered with busy patterns and colors can detract from the integrity of children's work.

Documenting learning processes and ongoing projects can also be an important part of classroom display.  It encourages students to reflect on their thought processes and past work.  Documentary display also allows teachers to reflect upon their practice.

Allowing ongoing projects to remain a part of the classroom display inspires children to continue thinking about the material throughout the school day. The presence of the rollercoaster on the outside windows of the classroom encourages children to discuss possible additions or changes, and keeps the concepts fresh in their minds.

culturePoints.text: Classroom displays should feature hands-on objects to promote curiosity and engagement. This requires establishing a classroom culture early in the year where students respect classroom property and are trusted to use it appropriately.

Here, student representations are displayed as an informational chart that illustrates the various characteristics of matter. This type of display emphasizes students' work as a source of information, validating their efforts and showing that their contributions to the classroom are valued.

Documentation displays that show photographs of children at work help engage parents in the life of the classroom and make them part of the learning community. Here, parents can see their children engaged in a long-term project, and can follow the evolution of the project step-by-step.

exPoints.text: Including books, posters, and 3D objects in your classroom displays provides children with experiences related to the curricular concepts. Here, teachers have set out simple inclined planes, small blocks of various shapes, and surfaces with different textures for children to explore, providing them with firsthand experiences.

Including reading materials and informational posters in classroom displays offers students thirdhand experiences that enhance their understanding of the concepts and provide background information for firsthand experiences.
Here, the classroom display includes photographs of students exploring the properties of different states of matter through firsthand experiences.

The display tells the story of a "solids hunt", where students went exploring outside and brought back a variety of items with different characteristics. They then categorized the items and wrote descriptions of them.

A student's representation of swings in motion reflects the child's firsthand experience on the playground. Including the representation in the classroom display reinforces for all the students that they experience the physical principles of force and motion every day.

repPoints.text: Student representations of concepts are the cornerstone of classroom display.  Making students' creative work visible in the classroom helps stimulate thinking and reinforces the concepts.
Students' 2-D representations, including labeled diagrams they create to represent their understanding, can be powerful components of a thought-provoking classroom display.

The students' 3D representation of a rollercoaster is mounted on the outside of the classroom, where it can remain while the building process continues. Displaying in-process projects like this one allows children to continually examine their work and add to it as they learn more about the concepts and big ideas.

As part of their unit on motion, the students collaborated on a large-scale mural on canvas, which represents their understanding of the physics at work at a local amusement park. The painting has become a permanent part of the school's hallway display.

video.description: This video depicts a variety of ways that classroom displays support the teaching of science for young children. Classroom displays should adapt to reflect the science content and children's evolving ideas.

enrich.intro: Before developing Display Setup, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It reflects children's culture and ideas
list.more: Integrating social studies with science, teachers had students create their self-portraits using many different kinds of solids.

list.text: It reflects the culture of the school
Displays of children's work include documentation
It includes children's on-going projects
list.more: A roller coaster that sent messages between two adjacent classrooms was built during a three-month period. As children gained more knowledge of the physical science content such as force and motion, kinetic and potential energy, and simple machines, they added new ideas to their project.

list.text: It includes places for the eye to rest and the mind to reflect
It does not rely on pre-packaged materials

challenges.theText:
My days are already so full, how can I fit in time to plan with other teachers?
It is often necessary to look for creative ways to make time for planning. You might turn a weekly lunchtime into a potluck gathering where a group of teachers share a meal and discuss the curriculum. You might schedule PE or extracurricular activities at the same time as your teaching partner and use that time to meet. Some teachers meet while classroom aides are supervising children outside. Others fit in brief 15-minute discussions on several different days each week.
Too often in schools we devote more time to discussing day-to-day nuts and bolts than we do planning curriculum goals. Trading some of the time ordinarily spent on procedures and using it instead for discussions of big ideas and concepts helps shift the focus to children's learning.How can teachers cover everything in the curriculum if they use this approach?
The classroom-ecosystem approach stresses depth over breadth. Therefore you should work in the beginning of the year to carefully select the areas you will spend more time on than others. Examine the curriculum and the science education standards and try to determine which concepts and big ideas will be most meaningful for children. Work with other teachers to eliminate the redundancies that rarely deepen understanding.
When teachers feel pressed to cover everything in the standards, the result is a watered down or disconnected program. If you approach the curriculum in terms of big ideas and concepts rather than topics and themes or isolated facts, you'll be better able to help children make connections and gain in-depth knowledge.Should a teacher ever say "no" to an idea or investigation that emerges from the student's?
Yes. A teacher's response to a student's idea or investigation should depend on his or her learning goal for the students. What might they learn from the idea? Does it fit with the science concepts and big ideas? Are there cost or safety concerns that might weigh against implementing this particular idea or investigation?
The fact that students are motivated to come up with ideas and ask questions indicates that the teacher is making science relevant and exciting. One way to determine whether ideas or investigations should be pursued is to ask which of the learning goals they will achieve.How much do teachers need to know about science to teach this way?
The stronger the teacher's knowledge of the content area the better he or she can help children build their own understanding. A strong knowledge base can also help teachers be sure of where they want to lead children in terms of the learning goals.
To increase their knowledge, teachers can read books, work with colleagues, use teacher guides or carefully selected internet sites, ask experts to come to the classroom, or attend professional development seminars.
Teachers who use the classroom-ecosystem approach need to see themselves as learners with the children, but they also must stay one step ahead, keeping in mind the concepts. Still, that doesn't mean they need to know it all. In the course of investigations children will come up with challenging questions. Teachers must know where to look for information and be willing to take the time to find it. A very important part of the classroom-ecosystem approach is this dynamic of constant learning on the part of both the teacher and the child.

pages.title: Resource Setup
pages.definition: Resources in the classroom should be readily accessible and include objects and materials that attract attention, invite curiosity, inspire discussion, and support a variety of ways of thinking and representing ideas. They should include objects found in nature, recycled materials and interesting or unusual books. There should be materials such as wood, wire, fabric, tiles, and paper of different sizes, shapes, textures and weight. There also should be a variety of art supplies such as charcoal, clay, paints, colored pencils and pastels.
pages.benefits: Resources provide children with the means to express themselves, support their learning process and communicate what they have learned. Offering a variety of interesting resources in a way that is readily accessible to children fosters independence and helps children grow as learners.
pages.examples: To represent the characteristics of a solid, the teacher provides students with a variety of natural materials that can be used to symbolize qualities such as "pointy," "rough," "crunchy" and "shiny."

video.title: Classroom Resources

planningPoints.text: Thinking about what materials children will need in their work is an important part of planning. When planning for a long-term project, teachers should consider asking parents to bring in modest materials and scraps for the children's use.

To support children's understanding of solids, the teacher planned an experience in which she provided a variety of rocks for the children to sort into groups according to characteristics.  She had the rocks waiting on tables for children when they returned from lunch so they could get to work right away.

In formal planning in the beginning of the year, the teacher arranged for every child to have a clipboard for recording observations. The sturdy clipboards can be taken on field trips and reused from year to year.
Teachers can work with their school or local librarian to select reading materials that enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas.

Including resources such as wheels and axles in the dramatic play area helps ensure that even unstructured choice time provides an opportunity to enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas.

setupPoints.text: Resources should include books, art supplies and an assortment of creative materials. To foster independence and creativity, children should be able to access resources when they need them and without assistance.

Grouping supplies in an attractive manner makes them inviting to children. It also inspires children to want to experiment with different media, which in turn enriches their work and provides multiple opportunities for assessment.

Resources are as much a part of the classroom's physical environment as the furniture and display boards.  Their visibility is a constant reminder to children that thinking is an active process, and that ideas should be recorded, experimented with, evaluated and revised.

Book displays should be changed and updated to correspond with the subject matter taught in the classroom. Here, a selection of books about force and motion and simple machines provide information related to the concepts and big ideas.
A small table display provides stimulating, unusual and thought-provoking items that children may explore on their own.

Asking classroom families to bring in modest materials and scraps can be an inexpensive way to support a large-scale project.  Designating a kid-friendly place in the classroom for these varied supplies broadens children's thinking and encourages creativity.

culturePoints.text: Setting up spaces where materials are stored in an attractive and welcoming way encourages pride in the learning environment and inspires children's thinking.
Storing materials so that they are always at hand tells children that they are capable, responsible members of the classroom community and that they have important work to do.

Communicating expectations and setting routines supports a classroom culture where everyone takes responsibility for their surroundings. In turn, children should be trusted to treat classroom property with respect and to work as independently as possible.

exPoints.text: To support children's understanding of solids, the teacher set out materials for a firsthand experience in which children sorted a variety of rocks into groups according to characteristics.

Books about force and motion and simple machines provide thirdhand experiences to enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas. Making reading materials readily available throughout the room encourages children to use books as a resource in their work and to explore science related materials during reading time.

A classroom setup that incorporates resources related to the concepts and big ideas encourages children to seek out firsthand experiences on their own. Observations and information gathered from these experiences can inform classroom discussions.

repPoints.text: Keep in mind that no one medium offers the best means of expression for every child. Offering a wide variety of materials to be used in representation helps children convey their understanding of concepts and big ideas and also can give the teacher a more accurate assessment of children's understanding.
Clipboards are one way to provide a convenient and efficient way for children to record observations. The observations will later inform children's representations of the concepts and big ideas.
Including a selection of nonfiction books amongst other hands-on materials encourages children to see the books as reference tools to be used in creating representations.
Resources for large-scale representations can include a variety of donated materials. Using donated or found materials keeps costs low and inspires children to extend their thinking.

video.description: This video depicts a variety of resources to be used in teaching science for young children. A variety of adaptable resources should be offered to support the science content and children's evolving ideas.

enrich.intro: Before developing Resource Setup, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It includes a variety of materials
list.more: Natural materials like these were offered to children to assist them in representing the different characteristics of a solid. Providing a variety of materials helps give students choices and assures that each child's work will be distinctive and unique.

list.text: Materials are accessible to children
list.more: To show their understanding of a force creating motion, students were asked to create a surface with friction and a surface without. These students independently look for materials that would best represent a bumpy, rough surface.
list.moreTwo: To help students get a better understanding of how simple machines work, a repair shop was set up in the classroom. To their delight the students were able to take apart the machines and see wheels, screws, wedges, inclined planes and levers.

list.text: Materials inspire imagination
Nothing in the room is off limits to children

challenges.theText:
My days are already so full, how can I fit in time to plan with other teachers?
It is often necessary to look for creative ways to make time for planning. You might turn a weekly lunchtime into a potluck gathering where a group of teachers share a meal and discuss the curriculum. You might schedule PE or extracurricular activities at the same time as your teaching partner and use that time to meet. Some teachers meet while classroom aides are supervising children outside. Others fit in brief 15-minute discussions on several different days each week.
Too often in schools we devote more time to discussing day-to-day nuts and bolts than we do planning curriculum goals. Trading some of the time ordinarily spent on procedures and using it instead for discussions of big ideas and concepts helps shift the focus to children's learning.How can teachers cover everything in the curriculum if they use this approach?
The classroom-ecosystem approach stresses depth over breadth. Therefore you should work in the beginning of the year to carefully select the areas you will spend more time on than others. Examine the curriculum and the science education standards and try to determine which concepts and big ideas will be most meaningful for children. Work with other teachers to eliminate the redundancies that rarely deepen understanding.
When teachers feel pressed to cover everything in the standards, the result is a watered down or disconnected program. If you approach the curriculum in terms of big ideas and concepts rather than topics and themes or isolated facts, you'll be better able to help children make connections and gain in-depth knowledge.Should a teacher ever say "no" to an idea or investigation that emerges from the student's?
Yes. A teacher's response to a student's idea or investigation should depend on his or her learning goal for the students. What might they learn from the idea? Does it fit with the science concepts and big ideas? Are there cost or safety concerns that might weigh against implementing this particular idea or investigation?
The fact that students are motivated to come up with ideas and ask questions indicates that the teacher is making science relevant and exciting. One way to determine whether ideas or investigations should be pursued is to ask which of the learning goals they will achieve.How much do teachers need to know about science to teach this way?
The stronger the teacher's knowledge of the content area the better he or she can help children build their own understanding. A strong knowledge base can also help teachers be sure of where they want to lead children in terms of the learning goals.
To increase their knowledge, teachers can read books, work with colleagues, use teacher guides or carefully selected internet sites, ask experts to come to the classroom, or attend professional development seminars.
Teachers who use the classroom-ecosystem approach need to see themselves as learners with the children, but they also must stay one step ahead, keeping in mind the concepts. Still, that doesn't mean they need to know it all. In the course of investigations children will come up with challenging questions. Teachers must know where to look for information and be willing to take the time to find it. A very important part of the classroom-ecosystem approach is this dynamic of constant learning on the part of both the teacher and the child.

pages.title: Culture
pages.quote: Visitors to UCLA Lab School are impressed by how articulate students are in describing their own learning processes. That lack of shame in incomplete mastery does not happen by accident. It is a matter of teachers managing the face threat potential of engaging students at the leading edge of their capacity, or in the zone of proximal development.
pages.citation: Adapted from Erickson, F., with Bagrodia, R., Cook-Sather, A., Espinoza, M., Jurow, S., Shultz, J. and Spencer, J. (2007). Students' Experience of School Curriculum: The Everyday Circumstances of Granting and Withholding Assent to Learn. In Connelly, F.M. et al (eds.), The Sage Handbook of Curriculum. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications, Inc., pp. 198-218.
pages.more: An effective classroom ecosystem is one in which teachers and students work together with mutual respect and as active participants in the learning process. Teachers facilitate active learning by providing opportunities for children to work in a variety of social arrangements; by modeling respect for ideas, encouraging questions, and valuing mistakes as part of learning; and by fostering children's independent use of resources to construct knowledge.

pages.title: Student-Student Culture
pages.definition: Children should be able to trust that they can work with their classmates in a socially safe environment. They should be able to avoid embarrassment, work without interference from other students when they wish to do so, and at other times work cooperatively with students, getting and giving help to one another in a timely way. Children should be given opportunities to work in a variety of configurations: individually, in pairs, in small groups of four or five, and as a whole group. Each configuration provides different opportunities to develop independence or to share work, negotiate ideas and conflicts, actively listen to other perspectives and develop relationships.
pages.benefits: Working together in conditions of mutual respect enriches children's personal relationships and improves verbal and nonverbal communication skills. When children work in a group they must be able to articulate their ideas without fear of harsh criticism or mockery from their fellow students. This candor helps students to deepen their understanding of concepts, which enhances their cognitive development. As children communicate about their thinking, they learn to speak in relationship to listening, and listen in relationship to speaking. In this way they challenge each others' thinking, with consideration for others, thus developing positive social skills.
pages.examples: In a large group, children discuss whether they should build their roller coaster inside or outside the classroom. The teacher acts as a facilitator while the children exchange ideas and concerns about the roller coaster's location. Children become invested in the process because they are given the opportunity to make decisions and come up with solutions.

video.title: The Roller Coaster

planningPoints.text: When the children came up with the idea to build a roller coaster, the teachers did project planning to ensure that there would be many opportunities for learning about the science concepts and big ideas.
In their project planning, teachers asked families to contribute scrap materials for use in building the roller coaster.

Part of the planning process was to group children into committees. These two students volunteered for the Building Committee. Committees are a good way to incorporate small-group work into class projects, and they mirror practices used in the adult workplace.

setupPoints.text: Teachers and children work on the roller coaster outside. Using outdoor space extends the learning environment and allows teachers and small groups to engage in detailed, concentrated work with fewer distractions.

Students and teachers chose to mount the roller coaster in a space where they can have easy, on-going access to it. This allows them to make revisions as needed and helps create an on-going dialogue about the project and the concepts.
The materials for the project are varied and accessible to all the children. The teacher encourages the children to decide which materials will work best for their purpose.
The materials include a jumble of donated scraps. Using donated and found materials keeps project costs low and inspires children to use creativity and imagination.

culturePoints.text: Although a teacher is present to supervise, the children are trusted to work on testing and improving the model roller coaster the group is building. They are able to work independently and productively because the teachers have set up routines to support this and children have had much practice working together.
Notice that the task requires the children to work cooperatively to solve the problem of how to get the ball through the tube. Real work in the world requires collaboration.

Notice how the children negotiate ideas, making suggestions and in turn being open to suggestions. Again, this kind of cooperative work is made possible by giving children many opportunities to work together.
The task engages the children and sustains their interest because it is in the context of a project they and their peers have generated.

exPoints.text: Working with a 3-D model provides children with firsthand experiences that make the concepts more tangible. Here the children can observe firsthand the effects of force and motion and the operation of simple machines such as inclined planes.

The students' building and testing of the roller coaster model is informed by previous experiences designed to illustrate the concepts. It also will provide context and help deepen understanding as they continue to explore the concepts and big ideas.

repPoints.text: The model roller coaster is a 3-D representation of concepts such as 'force causes motion and simple machines make work easier'.

Before beginning construction of the roller coaster, the children created 2-D representations of the components, such as inclined planes. In their drawings and paintings the children recorded their observations and then used those observations to inform the building of their 3-D representations.

The students' testing leads to observations about what makes sections of the roller coaster function, and this in turn leads to revisions to the model. Revising their 3-D representations allows children to deepen their understanding and formulate new questions.

video.description: During their study of simple machines, force and motion, and kinetic and potential energy, students decided to build a roller coaster that sends messages from one classroom to another. In this video, two children are working on the roller coaster model.
video.standards:
The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background.
  2. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time.
  3. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull.
  4. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move.
  5. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

enrich.intro: Before developing Student-Student Culture, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: The classroom space supports the variety of ways that children learn
Teachers trust children to work in small groups without adult guidance
list.more: Giving children opportunities to work with peers and to manage their own learning helps them become more engaged in the work and more likely to gain deep understanding of the concepts. To help ensure that the small groups are successful, teachers need to set up clear expectations for how children work together, and they need to communicate these expectations early and often.

list.text: Frequent conversations encourage differing perspectives and ideas
list.more: Discussion and negotiation help children make sense of the concepts, the big ideas and the learning experiences. As children talk to one another they have natural opportunities to question and explain, to sort out what they do and do not understand and to revise their thinking. This active processing of ideas makes the content more memorable and engaging for students. It also helps students develop work and social skills that will be useful throughout their lives.

challenges.theText:
How can I be sure students are learning if there is no teacher or adult at a table?
The classroom-ecosystem approach to teaching and learning is based on the belief that children are naturally curious and capable of learning independently.
To help ensure that the learning goals are met, set up experiences and materials that are engaging for children and have purpose. Everything on the table should be connected to the concepts and big ideas.
The way teachers put out materials is also important. For example, provide tools such as magnifying glasses to accompany experiences. Set out books with intriguing photos to help children in their research. Make sure there are sharpened pencils and different types of paper for children to use. Inviting materials help engage children in the learning experiences and encourage them to record their ideas and their understanding.
When is there time in the day for conversation and discussion? How do I best facilitate them?
Children need to have opportunities throughout the day to share their work with the teacher and each other and to discuss their hypotheses, predictions and thoughts for further study. This is when critical thinking and deep learning happen.
After each work time hold a debriefing. Follow firsthand, secondhand and thirdhand experiences and any kind of representation of understanding with a conversation. These conversations can be one-on-one with a teacher or involve the whole group. Whenever possible, include time for both types of discussion.
The best way to facilitate conversation is through asking open-ended questions and allowing children to answer without fear of judgment. For example, ask children: What did you notice? How did this thing compare to that one? What are some things that are similar, different? What if we were to add this? What do you predict will happen? How can you record what happened?
Conversations are most effective when the class is gathered in a common space, such as on the rug, rather than in desks or in rows of chairs. Sitting together in a circle on the rug helps make clear that everyone is a potential contributor and everyone's contribution is valued.
How do I encourage students who have a hard time participating in discussions?
Each child has something valuable and important to offer the learning community. It's important for teachers to unlock that gift, to find a child's strengths and what really interests her or him. This takes a lot of listening to and observing children, but it pays off in richer, fuller class discussions and deeper understanding of the concepts for all the children. If a child is quiet or reticent, put him in charge of a project he can share and feel proud of. Facilitate conversations so not only the same children are answering. Give quieter children time to answer. Modeling a respectful way to converse helps everyone learn how to be part of a productive work group.
What are some ways to build "community" in my classroom?
Setting up reasonable expectations for behavior and making sure children know what those expectations are helps build a community where everyone takes responsibility for himself or herself and everyone takes on the role of contributor.
In the beginning of the year and throughout the year, talk to children about taking care of their learning environment and keeping it beautiful. Emphasize that each person is an integral part of that. Build in lessons about how to take care of materials by putting caps on markers, cleaning up paintbrushes, putting away supplies, etc.
Model respect for children to help ensure that they will respect you and the other adults and children in the classroom. Even small things such as speaking to children warmly and with respect for their intelligence, displaying their work without added adornment, and giving them the time they need to complete tasks or answer questions help create a constructive community.

pages.title: Teacher-Student Culture
pages.definition: Children should be able to trust that they can work comfortably with their teacher in the presence of their fellow students. They should be able to avoid embarrassment as they interact with their teacher, work without interruption when that is appropriate, ask for help from the teacher, and get help in a timely way, when they need it. The teacher's role in the classroom ecosystem is one of active listener, facilitator of ideas and researcher.
pages.benefits: When the social arrangement of the classroom as a workplace for learning is one in which children feel safe to ask questions and take intellectual risks they become deeper thinkers and more invested learners. Addressing children's individual needs, integrating their ideas into instruction, and encouraging questions helps all children feel they have a contribution to make. As children see their ideas becoming an important part of classroom life, they feel invested in the classroom community and are more open and ready to take on new learning. They develop strong learning morale.
pages.examples: To assess a student's understanding of a concept, the teacher asks him to explain his reasoning. During the course of his explanation, the child realizes that he doesn't quite understand and he begins to question his reasoning. Rather than criticizing the child for being "wrong" or telling him the "right" answer, the teacher allows the student time to explain his thinking and helps to scaffold his understanding through inquiry.

video.title: Alex Being Forthright - and Mistaken

planningPoints.text: The idea to build a roller coaster was generated by the children. The teachers did careful planning to align the project with the concepts and big ideas.

The teacher planned this time to work with a small group of students to assess their understanding of the concepts of kinetic and potential energy. Meanwhile, a teaching assistant and a parent volunteer work with the other children on another aspect of the roller coaster project.

After realizing the students in the small group were confused about the concepts, the teacher brought the discussion to the whole group. This required flexibility in planning and a willingness to allow the children's needs to influence the course of instruction.
After this discussion, the teacher will do additional planning with her colleagues to clarify her own understanding of the scientific concepts and determine how best to clarify them for the students.

setupPoints.text: When setting up a large project, consider all aspects of the learning environment. Using outdoor space, when possible, provides opportunities for small group work and allows for in-depth, uninterrupted discussion.

Throughout the work space, resources are accessible to all the children. Note the canisters of building materials on the countertop. When the camera zooms out, notice the paint bottles to the left of the sink and the materials in storage tables at the far right. These important supplies are stored at children's height and are available as they need them.

The roller coaster is mounted on the outside of the classroom windows and remains there for the duration of the project. Displaying on-going work helps stimulate thinking, creativity and discussion, and integrates the project into the life of the classroom.

Notice the photos displayed behind the roller coaster. They tell the story of the project thus far. Displaying documentation of the group's planning and thinking process provides context for the project, gives teachers and children opportunities for reflection, and offers parents a way to connect with the children's work.

Student work, including paintings depicting force and motion, is displayed prominently in the classroom. The displays help stimulate thinking, create dialogue and convey that the children's work is valued.

culturePoints.text: Notice the teacher's request: "Alex, you gotta explain that." Without a lot of prior work on making it safe to say what you think when the teacher asks, this request would be intimidating to a child.

Notice that Alex is comfortable expressing his ideas. Although he is slightly wrong about the concepts, discussing them will help him refine his understanding and work toward a notion of potential energy being gained or lost as it trades off with kinetic energy (energy of motion).

The teacher realizes there is something that doesn't add up, but she doesn't tell the child he's wrong or correct him. Instead she tries to help him clarify his understanding by engaging him in dialogue.

Now the child realizes he isn't right, but he is still being candid. Although the stakes for embarassment are higher, he still says what he thinks. An effective classroom culture values learning as a process and allows children to revise their thinking through discussion and interaction.

Note that the teacher could have let the misconception pass, but she doesn't. Because she has established the classroom as a socially safe environment, she knows she can engage the whole group in the discussion.

Alex is saying that the message ball is gaining kinetic energy when it is going down. Notice he is still willing to share his ideas openly, even when he is in front of the whole class. Notice, too, that everyone is respectful as he speaks.

Here the teacher has noticed another child has something to say. Together the teacher and children construct a discussion in which children say what they think and no one attacks their ideas or pokes fun. The clear message is that the classroom is a safe place where thoughts can be expressed without negative consequences.

Notice how the teacher picks up on the child's question, "When it's going down it's going faster. So how is it losing speed?" When the teacher says, "That's confusing," she underscores the dissonance between the ideas and models how to think through a problem
As discussions and re-teaching continue, the teacher will use what the children are saying to distinguish between speed and total energy and between kinetic and potential energy.

For more about the story of the roller coaster, go to the Flexible Planning video, which shows how the teachers did research to clarify their understanding of kinetic and potential energy and then brought the information to the children.

exPoints.text: The children began building the roller coaster toward the end of the school year, but they had been building knowledge of the concepts since September. For example, a trip to a local amusement park allowed the children to explore the concepts of force and motion and kinetic and potential energy through firsthand experiences with roller coasters.
The students have firsthand experiences as they use the roller coaster model to apply their knowledge of the concepts.

The children are able to discuss scientific ideas because they have had many experiences throughout the year that were designed to familiarize them with the concepts. These included building and testing model inclined planes and experimenting with simple machines.

repPoints.text: Using their knowledge of the concepts, the students have built a 3-D working model of a roller coaster.  A student uses text to label the roller coaster where he thinks kinetic and potential energy are at work.

As the student explains his reasoning for labeling the parts of the roller coaster, he finds he is confused about the concepts. Having children talk about their work is an excellent way to assess their understanding and provides an opportunity to clarify the concepts.
Notice the paintings displayed above and to the right of the white board. They are 2-D representations of the children's understanding of force and motion.

Giving children the opportunity to represent their thinking in different ways (i.e., orally, by drawing and painting, and by building a 3-D model) helps children understand the 'how, what' and 'why' of a concept. It also offers multiple entry points to accommodate different learning styles.

video.description: In the sequence before this video begins, the teacher had asked children to label their roller coaster at the points where the ball achieves maximum kinetic and potential energy. When Alex explains his placement of the labels, it becomes apparent that he is confusing velocity with the distinction between kinetic and potential energy. The teacher recognizes this and makes a plan to help him refine his understanding. (For more on how she and her colleague re-teach the concepts to clear up the misconceptions, go to the Example Video in Flexible Planning.)
video.concept: Energy is stored and energy is released
video.standards: The concepts here go beyond the standards, but it was important to address them because they came up in the context of the project.

enrich.intro: Before developing Student-Student Culture, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: Frequent conversations encourage differing perspectives and ideas
Teachers actively listen to children's ideas and emergent thinking
list.more:
Active listening on the part of the teacher encourages children to express their ideas. It helps children develop confidence and empowers them to take an active role in the learning process. This sets up a different kind of relationship in the classroom, one that is less focused on the teacher imparting knowledge and more on teachers and students working together to construct knowledge.
When teachers take the time to listen to children's ideas they get to know their students better and see their potential and their individuality. Strong knowledge of their students helps teachers become better at assessing learning and is a key factor in children's academic success.

list.text: Teachers see themselves as researchers and facilitators of children's learning
The classroom space is comfortable and sparks children's curiosity
list.more: Providing children with a comfortable, inviting physical environment lets them know that they are valued and encourages their cooperative participation in the learning community. An attractive, functional space in which children can easily access resources and work both independently and cooperatively invites them to engage with the concepts and big ideas. When the physical environment is safe and inviting, opportunities emerge for children to share their ideas and understanding with one another and to learn through their interactions with teachers and peers.

list.text: Teachers display student work without embellishments

challenges.theText:
How can I be sure students are learning if there is no teacher or adult at a table?
The classroom-ecosystem approach to teaching and learning is based on the belief that children are naturally curious and capable of learning independently.
To help ensure that the learning goals are met, set up experiences and materials that are engaging for children and have purpose. Everything on the table should be connected to the concepts and big ideas.
The way teachers put out materials is also important. For example, provide tools such as magnifying glasses to accompany experiences. Set out books with intriguing photos to help children in their research. Make sure there are sharpened pencils and different types of paper for children to use. Inviting materials help engage children in the learning experiences and encourage them to record their ideas and their understanding.
When is there time in the day for conversation and discussion? How do I best facilitate them?
Children need to have opportunities throughout the day to share their work with the teacher and each other and to discuss their hypotheses, predictions and thoughts for further study. This is when critical thinking and deep learning happen.
After each work time hold a debriefing. Follow firsthand, secondhand and thirdhand experiences and any kind of representation of understanding with a conversation. These conversations can be one-on-one with a teacher or involve the whole group. Whenever possible, include time for both types of discussion.
The best way to facilitate conversation is through asking open-ended questions and allowing children to answer without fear of judgment. For example, ask children: What did you notice? How did this thing compare to that one? What are some things that are similar, different? What if we were to add this? What do you predict will happen? How can you record what happened?
Conversations are most effective when the class is gathered in a common space, such as on the rug, rather than in desks or in rows of chairs. Sitting together in a circle on the rug helps make clear that everyone is a potential contributor and everyone's contribution is valued.
How do I encourage students who have a hard time participating in discussions?
Each child has something valuable and important to offer the learning community. It's important for teachers to unlock that gift, to find a child's strengths and what really interests her or him. This takes a lot of listening to and observing children, but it pays off in richer, fuller class discussions and deeper understanding of the concepts for all the children. If a child is quiet or reticent, put him in charge of a project he can share and feel proud of. Facilitate conversations so not only the same children are answering. Give quieter children time to answer. Modeling a respectful way to converse helps everyone learn how to be part of a productive work group.
What are some ways to build "community" in my classroom?
Setting up reasonable expectations for behavior and making sure children know what those expectations are helps build a community where everyone takes responsibility for himself or herself and everyone takes on the role of contributor.
In the beginning of the year and throughout the year, talk to children about taking care of their learning environment and keeping it beautiful. Emphasize that each person is an integral part of that. Build in lessons about how to take care of materials by putting caps on markers, cleaning up paintbrushes, putting away supplies, etc.
Model respect for children to help ensure that they will respect you and the other adults and children in the classroom. Even small things such as speaking to children warmly and with respect for their intelligence, displaying their work without added adornment, and giving them the time they need to complete tasks or answer questions help create a constructive community.

pages.title: Experiences
pages.quote: A multiplicity of our five senses, the only avenues into the brain, are activated through firsthand experiences.
pages.citation:
Lowery, L. (1998).
The Biological Basis of Thinking and Learning (Monograph), p. 18
Berkeley, CA: Lawrence Hall of Science.
pages.more: Before children can formulate questions or show what they know, they have to be provided with experiences related to the content. Once children have been provided background knowledge either through firsthand or secondhand experiences, they are ready to work with text, which both uses and deepens prior knowledge. The goal in providing children with a variety of experiences is to help them move from novice to expert in their understanding and their ability to apply their knowledge of the concepts.

pages.title: Representation
pages.quote: Different forms of representation evoke, develop, and refine the modes of thinking that contribute to the cultivation of what is broadly called mind... By no means is thinking limited to what words alone can carry.
pages.citation:
Eisner, E. (December 2003/January 2004).
Preparing for Today and Tomorrow,
Educational Leadership, p. 6
pages.more:
Representation is the means by which students demonstrate and communicate their knowledge of big ideas and concepts both to the teacher and to themselves. Students create representations in a variety of ways, including drawing, writing, graphing, sculpting and movement. This work can be categorized into four key formats--oral/textual, kinesthetic, two-dimensional and three-dimensional--each of which offers unique opportunities for children to deepen their understanding. (See General Guidelines for Choosing a Representational Format)

Deep understanding of a concept includes knowing about its structure, its behavior and its function, or the "what," the "how," and the "why" of the concept. For example, to understand the concept "Simple machines make work easier," students must know what are the different parts of the simple machine (structure), how the simple machine works (behavior) and why it makes work easier (function). One type of representation may help students see the "what" while another may help them see the "how."

Additionally, asking children to create multiple representations of concepts and big ideas helps them to synthesize and build knowledge. Offering opportunities to represent concepts in a variety of ways helps to ensure that children with differences in learning style, previous experiences and background knowledge will be engaged and invested in the learning process. At the same time, representation provides important tools for assessing children's understanding and allows the teacher to make informed decisions about instruction. The result is greater effectiveness in addressing children's individual learning needs, which ultimately helps ensure academic success for every child.
